PositionHistory.Title: Senior Consultant
PositionHistory.OrganizationName: Instructional Designer and e-Learning Content Developer

Description.p: Ms. Allen has over 20 years of experience in the corporate training arena with a focus in both e-Learning and classroom delivery. She has the know-how to work collaboratively with a team to move a training initiative through all development phases.

Most recently she utilized the Articulate Studio rapid e-learning software suite to design and create End User Training for Hewlett-Packard's Business Technology Optimization software. She also documented the best practices and standards so that this curriculum was consistent and cohesive. This standards document then became a guidebook for the client to maintain and create courses.

Ms. Allen has also been instrumental in the development of the Applied Dynamic e-Learning Processes & Tools (ADEPT) model for Avalon Consulting. By researching best practices in the industry she helps keep the methodology current and to the point.

Ms. Allen and the Avalon team utilized the GoCourse technology to create a business essentials certification program for the University of North Carolina's Kenan-Flagler Business School. During this project, Ms. Allen worked with professors to aid them in creating their own online content, developed courses and produced the standards guide.

Ms. Allen has worked on several successful Vignette User Education (VUE) customization projects. These projects entail working with the client to identify system modifications and then translating those changes to the course. This includes changing the terminology, colors, logos, screen shots, etc. of an existing VUE course to match the client's specific system workflow and branding. The courses are created and updated using the Articulate Studio product suite. Ms. Allen taught workshops to train clients to maintain their own VUE courses.

She also used her systems background and instructional design knowledge to develop systems documentation coupled with Web-based courses, including simulations, to highlight how to use a new corporate system for Catholic Health Initiatives, a $7 billion national hospital chain. She has also utilized her facilitation skills to assist clients in documenting workflow patterns that will ultimately require training.

Ms. Allen was the lead instructional designer for the development of a multi-media Web-based course for the Ft. Worth (Texas) Independent School District. This course, using Texas Education Agency standards, was designed to teach educators how a student acquires a new language and the laws in place regarding students who are learning English as a second language. She was instrumental in facilitating the collection of course material, designing the course structure, scripts, interactions, and audio narration.

As a former trainer, Ms. Allen understands the learning patterns of end-users and is committed to creating quality, intuitive Web resources. She approaches projects from a new-user perspective to ensure the design and user interface are consistent and user-friendly. Ms. Allen enjoys working with clients to help them achieve their business goals.

Drawing on her lecture-style training background, Ms. Allen designed and developed the first Web-based training course for the EDS sales community. This course convinced sales leadership that Web-based training is an effective training solution. Ms. Allen is detail oriented and strives to make Web sites and documents easy to navigate and read.

To expand her general human resources knowledge, Ms. Allen became the project manager for a global HR business partner. She coordinated the rollout of compensation and succession planning for a line of business and gained an appreciation for the business challenges and obstacles faced by leaders. Ms. Allen met regularly with leaders to discuss project status and thus refined her presentation and writing skills.

Ms. Allen began her training career as an MS Office instructor. During this time, she realized a personal desire to help others achieve their business goals by teaching them the software skills necessary to succeed. After developing her classroom techniques, Ms. Allen taught other technical professionals the classroom skills necessary to become effective trainers.

Ms. Allen started her corporate career as a financial analyst. She created monthly financial reports, wrote general ledger entries, developed budgets, and participated in the monthly accounting cycle. These duties gave her an appreciation for the business and financial side of all business activities.
